About the ICT Procurement Guidelines in Portugal¶

Strategic Guidelines¶

In December 2011, the Portuguese Government approved a Global Strategic Plan for Rationalisation and Cost Reduction in ICT in the Public Administration 1 that includes two policy measures:

  • Cost reduction (measure 3.6) and

  • Adoption of Open-Source Software (measure 3.21).

PT Guidelines 1

3.21. Adoption of Open-Source Software in the Public Administration IT systems

  • This measure aims to encourage a rigorous evaluation by the Government of more efficient software solutions by promoting the use of open source software in the information systems of the Public Administration, whenever the maturity and cost are favourable.

  • This measure […] shall promote the study of which software tools should henceforth be used by the Public Administration (such use being either recommended or mandatory).

  • […] The use of open-source software, produced by the Public Administration, private companies or the civilian society, and available under the EUPL approved by the European Commission, shall be encouraged.

  • […] In alignment with the measure 3.6 (Evaluation of ICT projects and expenses), before the procurement or acquisition of any IT solution or software development services, contracting authorities must always quantify the Total Cost of Ownership (TCO), based on explicit technical requirements and any collateral costs of the solution.

  • The TCO analysis is mandatory, whenever comparing non-open source products and solutions with open source products and solutions.

These measures are similar to the ones adopted by the UK Government in 2011 2 .

UK Guidelines 3

  1. The Government will actively and fairly consider open source solutions alongside proprietary ones in making procurement decisions,

  2. Procurement decisions will be made on the basis of the best value for money solution to the business requirement, taking account of total lifetime cost of ownership of the solution, including exit and transition costs, after ensuring that solutions fulfil minimum and essential capability, security, scalability, transferability, support and manageability requirements.

  3. The Government will expect those putting forward IT solutions to develop where necessary a suitable mix of open source and proprietary products to ensure that the best possible overall solution can be considered.

  4. Where there is no significant overall cost difference between open and non-open source products, open source will be selected on the basis of its additional inherent flexibility.

Similar guidelines have been issued by the European Commission 5, by the French government 4, etc..

Procurement Guidelines¶

In December 2012, the Portuguese State Budget Law for 2013 6 further limits the adquisition of proprietary software solutions.

Expenditure on acquisition of software (including software development and software licence renewal) is only allowed if the absence of alternative free open source software (FOSS) solutions is demonstrated or the total cost of ownership of FOSS solution is higher, including all possible costs of maintenance, adaptation, migration or exit.

Such cost-benefit analysis and demonstration must be submitted to the Portuguese Agency for Administrative Modernization (http://www.ama.pt), for review and formal approval prior to the start of any call for tenders.

The Software selection process described in this documentation was part of the necessary analysis.

Technological Guidelines¶

Likewise, the tender specifications and the generic solution components must be formally approved by AMA.
